The Board of Trustees offers an opportunity for the public to address the Board in four sections of the agenda: on matters of concern about Closed Session items; on matters not appearing on the agenda; on action items contained in the Consent Agenda; and prior to voting on any item contained in the Action Agenda. Each speaker is encouraged to submit a comment card to the Board clerk in order to be recognized to speak.
	Per Board Policy, three minutes may be allotted to each speaker with a maximum of 30 minutes per subject. No action or discussion shall be undertaken on any public comments except that members of the Board or its staff may briefly respond to or ask a question for clarification regarding statements made or questions posed by persons addressing the Board under this agenda item.
	For information and disability access to materials, call 408-270-6402. Meetings are held in a location accessible to the disabled.

Board Policy 7080.203 defines Class III records as including, but not limited to, detailed records related to:  records basic to an audit, including those relating to attendance, average daily attendance, or a business or financial transaction (purchase orders, invoices, warrants, ledger sheets, canceled checks and stubs, student body and cafeteria fund records, etc.), and detailed records used in the preparation of any other report.
	 
Board Policy 7080.204 states that Class III records basic to an audit shall not be destroyed until after the third July 1st succeeding the completion of the audit required by Education Code 84040 or of any other legally required audit, or after the ending date of any retention period by an agency other than the State of California, whichever date is later.
	 
Fiscal Services has the following Class III records that meet the three-year criteria for destruction:
	 
Paid Invoices from Fiscal Year 2008-2009
Cash Receipts from Fiscal Year 2008-2009
Financial Aid Reports from Fiscal Year 2008-2009
Budget Transfers from Fiscal Year 2008-2009
Petty Cash Reimbursements from Fiscal Year 2008-2009

Cash/Bank Reconciliations from Fiscal Year 2008-2009
Journal Vouchers from Fiscal Year 2008-2009
Canceled Checks from Fiscal Year 2008-2009
Refund Requests from Fiscal Year 2008-2009
Purchase Orders from Fiscal Year 2008-2009

The SB1070 CTE Southwest Pathways Consortium (SWPC) is a partnership effort between 14 community colleges and is geographically framed by the southwest region of the San Francisco Bay Area.  
	 
The purpose of the SB1070 CTE Pathways Program grant is to align Career and Technical Education (CTE) programming, policies, and procedures throughout the system that will result in measureable and successful transition of CTE students from high school to post-secondary education and training in careers of high need, high growth, or emerging regional sectors.  
	 
SWPC has established five workgroups which consist of:  (1) Systems Alignment, (2) Data Systems, (3) Industry Partnerships, (4) Professional Development/Best Practices, and (5) Marketing/Branding. These workgroups will be used to carry out the planning and implementation activities of the grant.
	 
This MOU is not a commitment of funds.  SWPC is funded by the California Community Colleges Chancellorâs Office (CCCCO) through SB1070 legislation that consists of three years of committed funding totaling $1,839,891:  
	 
Planning Year:  Jan 2014-Dec 2014
Implementation Year 1:  Jan 2015-Dec 2015
Implementation Year 2:  Jan 2016-Dec 2016

The South Bay Consortia for Adult Education (SBCAE) is the consortia formed to develop the south bay Regional Plan for Adult Education of which San Jose Evergreen Community College District is one of seven districts playing an active role. On October 14, staff presented an information item to the Board of Trustees designed to provide an update on AB 86 Objectives and Progress Reporting, SBCAEâs regional leadership, and the breadth of stakeholder involvement in the development of the regional plan for adult education. At that meeting representatives from the Academic Senate presented public testimony and a formal letter noting that while faculty were involved in "expert panels" to advice the consortium they were nevertheless not involved at the SBCAE Steering Committee level. It is the faculty contention that the Consortium would be well served by including the voice of the faculty at the highest planning level.
	 
The Board of Trustees recognizes the organizational collaborative structure of the consortium; nevertheless, it agreed that a request to reconsider the role of faculty at the Steering Committee level should be advanced to the Consortium at the earliest time possible. 
	 
	 
Attached is a copy of the Academic Senate Letter.
items.item_recommendation: Recommendation that the Chancellor request that the SBCAE reconsider inclusion of K-12 and Community College Faculty in the Steering Committee.

This month is designated by Congress as “National Disability Employment Awareness Month.”  The origins of this commemoration began in 1945 when Congress passed Joint Resolution 23 and later updated and expanded the law to a month-long commemoration in 1988 to acknowledge the employment needs and contributions of individuals with all types of disabilities
More recently, ACR 162 (Senator Beall) was passed by the California State Senate and by the California State Assembly which designates the 2nd week in October of each year as “Disability History Week.”   
	 
Locally, over 1,500 students with disabilities are served by the San Jose/Evergreen Community College District.  As such, it is especially important that our Board acknowledge, celebrate and promote the history of disabilities and the disability rights movement.

items.item_details:
On, September 9, 2014, the Board of Trustees expressed interest in discussing student enrollment and its impact on the Districtâs budget. The Board was specifically interested in the steps the colleges have taken to address enrollment declines.
 
For the past five years (2009-2014) at SJECCD, student enrollment has declined by 18.28% .  This includes a decline at Evergreen Valley College of 11% and at San Jose City College of 23%. At the onset, this was a planned and managed decline put in place to address severe state budget cuts facing all community colleges statewide.  In our case, the cuts were also prompted by a  past ongoing history of  "unfunded FTES"; in other words, the enrollment of large numbers of students for which we received no state support.   As always trends must be viewed in context and there are several factors worth nothing:
	 
1.  During much of that five year period our district met the established State Cap
2.  During that same five year period all 10 community colleges in  the Bay Area watched their student enrollment decline in numbers ranging from 11% to 30%.
3.  In the FY12-13 SJECCD became a Basic Aid District and the state enrollment Cap benchmark is no longer the key factor in enrollment management.
	 
As a "Basic Aid" District, SJECCD's Enrollment Management Goals are now dependent on two factors:
	 
1.  Board Ends Policies for Student Success
2.  Increased availability of resources which, through board directive, must be maximize to serve the highest number of students.
3.  Enrollment management goals
	 
	 
The purpose of this information item is to inform the Board about the enrollment management efforts that have taken place at the colleges, explain the effort and products produced by the District-wide Enrollment Management Task-force, and describe next steps for how the district will approach enrollment management within the "Basic Aid" funding construct and the "Ends Policies" for student success adopted by the Board.
	 
Attachments include an outline of the presentation; proposed charge of the Enrollment Management Committee; District enrollment management principles, philosophy, and definition.
